awd_titl_txt: Opportunistic complexation and mesoscopic aggregates in protein solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Opportunistic complexation and mesoscopic aggregates in protein solution

Protein aggregation is a central problem of biophysics and other life sciences. This investigation focuses on a particularly puzzling type of protein aggregation during which protein-rich inclusions form in protein solutions.  These inclusions are a micron or less in size and have been called the "mesoscopic clusters". Despite their small volume, the clusters are essential nucleation sites for ordered protein solids such as crystals and sickle cell anemia fibers. The mesoscopic clusters are also at odds with standard notions of thermodynamics, which dictates that such clusters should be either much larger or should not exist at all.  Understanding the molecular origin of the mesoscopic clusters will resolve a major fundamental question of thermodynamics. This research will test the hypothesis that the mesoscopic clusters are caused by formation of long-lived complexes made up of individual protein molecules. A combination of advanced experimental techniques, theoretical modeling, and computer simulations will be employed to test this hypothesis.  Understanding protein aggregation has implications in all facets of biology as well as on biotechnology and health. At the core of the broader impact activities is training of graduate, undergraduate, and, in particular, high school students.  The project is a multidisciplinary study that spans many topics in physics, chemistry, and biology and represents a great platform for further academic endeavors of the involved students.

The microscopic hypothesis underlying the proposed work is that the mesoscopic clusters stem from the formation of transient protein-containing complexes.  The complexes are stabilized at high protein densities.  In contrast with the bulk solution, the complexes are the dominant protein-containing species inside the clusters. In a steady-state cluster, the influx of protein in the form of monomers is exactly balanced by the outflow of protein in the form of complexes.  The nature of the complex depends on whether the protein is monomeric, as is lysozyme, or oligomeric, as is hemoglobin, ordinarily a tetrameric protein.  The investigators in this study hypothesize that for typically monomeric proteins, complex formation is accompanied by partial protein unfolding and, possibly, domain swapping.  In the case of oligomeric proteins, the complexes are oligomers that contain an untypical number of individual monomers.  A core aspect of the hypothesis is that the complexes are opportunistic; they represent untypical ways to transiently bind individual protein molecules together.  The research team will establish the identity and mechanisms of the complexation using a combination of physicochemical and biochemical experimental techniques (dynamic light scattering, Brownian microscopy, mass spectroscopy, amide exchange NMR, sheer flow) and theoretical tools (molecular modeling employing coarse-grained energy functions and the classical density functional theory).  They will test whether the clusters are truly steady-state objects and explore the possibility that cluster formation has a slow, irreversible component.  This part of the proposed study may answer the question whether clusters ripen according to an Ostwald-like scenario, or a different mechanism is involved.

por.por_cntn:
This study attacked a puzzling anomaly observed in liquid solutions of many proteins and other, less complex molecules. One of the PIs, Dr. Vekilov, made a startling discovery in 2005 that a seemingly unremarkable solution of the protein lysozyme, a common protein that is part of the egg white, hosts what looks like alien objects. Dubbed "mesoscopic clusters", because of their sub-micron size, these alien objects are too small to be seen by ordinary microscopy, let alone by the naked eye, but reveal themselves in dynamic light scattering experiments. Individual clusters can be tracked using advanced fluorescence techniques and have been seen by electron microscopy in flash frozen solutions, too. We now know that the clusters are made up of a liquid that has a higher concentration of the protein than the surrounding solution. Despite their small volume, the clusters are essential nucleation sites for ordered protein solids such as crystals and sickle cell anemia fibers. The mesoscopic clusters are in conflict with standard notions of thermodynamics, which dictate that clusters of a distinct phase should be either much larger or should not exist at all. Instead, there is a steady ensemble of the clusters that is established soon after the solution is prepared. Meeting this scientific challenge is of utmost importance, considering that nucleation is a major route to making solids and, generally, material design.

A collaboration between and experimenter (Vekilov) and theoretician (Lubchenko), the work used a two-prong strategy to test the microscopic hypothesis that there is a specific molecular process underlying the emergence of the clusters that had not been apparent before. We had conjectured that the solute molecules, be it protein or another chemical species, form long-lived complexes consisting of two or more solute molecules. The stability and lifetime of these complexes are just large enough to transiently stabilize the formation of small droplets of a relatively concentrated solution but not large enough to drive a full-scale condensation of the concentrated solution. 

On the theoretical side, we have definitively confirmed that the complexation scenario can, in fact, lead to nucleation of droplets of a concentrated solution that are less stable than the surrounding solvent. The droplets can grow, despite the process being uphill (!), and then decay because of a mechanical instability. This fundamental result came about in the form of a previously unknown solution of equations that describe, simultaneously, chemical reaction and diffusion of the reactants. These results also shed light on the puzzling way the clusters ripen in freshly made solution. We have confirmed an important aspect of the complexation scenario that the protein lysozyme must partially unfold in order for the complexes to be of just the right stability.

On the experimental side, we have shown that the mesoscopic clusters are, in fact, present in solutions of a variety of proteins that we know tend to form transient complexes. The proteins themselves are part of the pathophysiology of major diseases, including the sickle cell disease, cancer, and the Alzheimer?s; thus the present studies of aggregation behaviors of those important proteins, we hope, will contribute to treating the corresponding illnesses. In a major breakthrough, we have discovered that the clusters form in solutions of other, non-biogenic molecules, such as the anti-psychotic medication olanzapine. We have established, consistent with the theoretical advances, that the conformational flexibility of the lysozyme is crucial for its ability to form the clusters. We have obtained foundational results demonstrating that the formation of mesoscopic clusters is, in fact, distinct, from other types of aggregation such as fibril formation. We have obtained direct evidence, for the first time, of crystal nucleation within the mesoscopic clusters.

At the center of the broader impact activities was training of graduate, undergraduate, and, in particular, high school students. The involved students have been exposed to and learned advanced experimental techniques, how to perform and manage massively parallel computer simulations, and theoretical thermodynamics at a level that could not be realized in a normal setting. Undergraduate and high school students co-authored peer-reviewed articles, while the high school students have entered premier undergraduate institutions in STEM fields.  The PI have created blogs and layperson?level media releases reaching out to millions of readers. A book incorporating advanced notions of Physical Chemistry for science majors is being written and is available online free of charge.
